clinical_study.brief_title: Validity and Reliability of the Turkish Version of WOOS
clinical_study.official_title: Validity and Reliability of the Turkish Version of Western Ontario Osteoarthritis of the Shoulder Index

brief_summary.textblock:
Purpose The aim of this study is to adapt the Western Ontario Osteoarthritis of the Shoulder Index (WOOS) specific to shoulder osteoarthritis, to Turkish and evaluate its validity and reliability.
Methods WOOS index was translated and culturally adapted to Turkish, systematically. It was applied to 68 patients with osteoarthritis of shoulder treated conservatively. The reliability of the scale was checked through internal consistency and test-retest methods. Internal consistency was analyzed with Cronbach's alpha value. Test-retest reliability was assessed using an intraclass correlation coefficient with 25 patients. The Western Ontario Rotator Cuff (WORC), The Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI), and The Society of American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons Standardized Shoulder Assessment (ASES) score were used to conduct concurrent validity.

detailed_description.textblock:
Shoulder osteoarthritis occurs as a result of progressive wear in the glenohumeral joint cartilage. It causes pain, stiffness, inflammation in surrounding soft tissues, and muscle weakness in the shoulder joint. The range of motion (ROM) of the shoulder joint is greater than the hip and knee joints, where osteoarthritis is more common, and a decrease in ROM as a result of osteoarthritis affects patients' psychological state more. These symptoms also affect negatively the functional level and quality of life of the patient. As the number of patients with shoulder osteoarthritis increases in the elderly population, it becomes more important to use disease-specific patient-related outcomes to compare treatment modalities and patient satisfaction.
Various clinical scales are available to investigate shoulder diseases. The Oxford Shoulder Score, ASES score, Long Head of Biceps (LHB) score, and Constant-Murley score, which are used in various pathologies of the shoulder, have been developed and tested in different languages. Furthermore, Turkish validations were made and culturally adapted in the Turkish population. However, none of them are specific for osteoarthritis of the shoulder.
Therefore; Lo et al. developed the WOOS index, which is specific for shoulder osteoarthritis. This scale is based on clinical functions of the shoulder joint as well as sports/recreation/work, lifestyle, and emotions. Although the WOOS index has been used as a valid and reliable tool in native English-speaking countries for the last two decades, its Turkish adaptation has not been done yet.
Thus, the aim of this study was to translate the WOOS index into the Turkish language and investigate the validity and reliability of the scale in the Turkish population.
At first, study permission was received via mail from the author who developed the WOOS index. Later, ethical approval was obtained from the clinical researches ethics committee (Number: 91610558-604.01.02-05.12.2019/12). Finally, the WOOS index was adapted into Turkish according to systematic translation rules, and then the validity and reliability of the translated scale were evaluated.
Translation and Cross-Cultural Adaptation Process The translation and cultural adaptation of the scale were performed according to the procedure of Beaton et al. In the first stage of adaptation, two native Turkish speakers, one from the medical sector and the other from outside the field, translated the original scale into Turkish. Two translation outputs were synthesized. Synthesized Turkish scale was translated back to English by two independent professional bilingual translators via a translation company. The working committee compared the translated document and the original scale in terms of meaning and usage of language and decided on the new version of the scale. The comprehensibility of the new version was pretested on 15 clinicians. They did not report any ambiguity or confusing meaning in the Turkish version. Therefore, the latest Turkish version of the WOOS index was created successfully.
Sixty-eight adult patients whose native language is Turkish and diagnosed with shoulder osteoarthritis by orthopaedists were included in the study. Patients with illiteracy, cognitive impairment, and shoulder circumference fractures were excluded.
Patients diagnosed at the hospital were oriented to Gazi University, Faculty of Health Sciences Department. There, patients were asked to complete the determined questionnaires under the supervision of a physical therapist. The demographics of the patients were recorded. After the examination, in addition to the medical treatment given by the physicians, an individual home treatment program was created by the Physiotherapist for each patient. In 25 patients, the WOOS index was repeated two days later.
Literature research was conducted to determine the correct evaluation criteria. The scales which were used in the development of the original WOOS index and in the other adaptation studies were analyzed. Scales have higher consistency with the WOOS index and also adapted in Turkish previously, were preferred. Thus; it was decided to use WORC, SPADI, and ASES questionnaires to evaluate the concurrent validity of the WOOS index.
The WOOS index is a self-administrated, disease-specific questionnaire for the measurement of the quality of life for patients with osteoarthritis of the shoulder. This scale consists of four sub-sections and nineteen items as SECTION A: Physical Symptoms (6 items), SECTION B: Sports/Recreation/Work (5 items), SECTION C: Lifestyle (5 items) and SECTION D: Emotions (3 items). All items are rating with a 10 cm-visual analog scale (VAS). "0" point indicates that the symptom is not experienced and "10" points indicate that it is experiencing severely. So; the sum of points is in the range of "0-1900" points. The percentage value of the total score can also be used as an outcome score.
WORC index is a self-assessment instrument that has been developed to measure the quality of life of patients with rotator cuff disease. It has five sub-sections (physical symptoms, sports, and recreation, work, lifestyle, emotions) and twenty-one items. Each question is rating with a 10cm-VAS. Total score changes between 0 and 2100 points. A score of 0 implies no symptoms, and a score of 2100 is the worst score possible.
SPADI was developed to measure current shoulder pain and disability. We preferred the numerical rating scale (NRS) version of SPADI. Each question is rating in the range of 0-10 points. The percentage of the total point is recorded for each domain. The total score was calculated in the same way.
The ASES score consists of two sections. One of them is the 10-item functional section (Likert type) rated by a physician and the other one 1-item pain section (VAS type) rated by the patient. A patient gets a minimum of 0, a maximum of 100 points. Higher points implicate better medical conditions for the patient.
All statistical analyses in this study were carried out with the Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS), Windows (version 22.0 SPSS for Windows; SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). The analyses were presented as mean (SD). The reliability of the scale was evaluated with internal consistency and test-retest methods. Test-retest studies are generally conducted in two or fourteen days' interval. This time is sufficient both to minimize the bias associated with the recollection of previous responses and to ensure to keep stable the clinical state of the patient. In order to stay stable the patients' clinical conditions, we preferred to apply retest before starting the treatment. So as not to delay the treatment, we preferred the two-day interval. Internal consistency was calculated with Cronbach Alpha value. Test-retest reliability was assessed using an intraclass correlation coefficient. The validity of the scale was evaluated in terms of concurrent validity. To assess the concurrent validity, total WOOS scores were compared with total scores of WORC, SPADI, and ASES; subsections of the WOOS index were also compared with subsections of WORC. All variables were analyzed in terms of normality. As all variables were nonparametric, the Spearman correlation coefficient method was used. For all calculations; p<.05 were considered significant.
